Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Asymmetric Protein Localization and Control of Stomatal Lineage Cell Fate
Award.AbstractNarration:
During development, all multicellular organisms face a similar set of challenges: they must create a diverse set of specialized cell types, organize these cells into functional tissues, and maintain pools of stem cells to replenish those tissues throughout their lifetimes. Asymmetric cell division, in which one cell divides to create daughter cells that differ in size, location and cellular components, is an important mechanism for solving these developmental challenges. While all organisms must solve the same problem of generating asymmetries, they do not always come up with the same answer. This project uses the development of stomata (epidermal structures that regulate CO2 and H2O exchange between the plant and atmosphere) as a model to understand how asymmetries are generated in plants. BASL protein, first identified by its role in stomatal development, is a plant-specific regulator of cell and tissue asymmetries, and will be used to identify the general components required for plant asymmetric cell divisions. Stomata not only provide a framework to discover fundamental developmental mechanisms, they function as major components of terrestrial water and carbon cycles. As we witness changes in the global climate, understanding the mechanisms by which plants control the density and pattern of stomata will be essential to produce food or fuel crops that withstand or mitigate production of detrimental climatic conditions.

This CAREER proposal integrates research, teaching and public outreach about genetics and developmental biology. A new course was designed to make students consumers of biological information from a variety of sources, including primary literature and the mainstream media. Then, in partnership with The Tech Museum, students will produce publicly accessible scientific articles. The Tech has programs designed to promote scientific literacy among the adults and children and these programs reach a broad audience including K-8 students in some of the most under-served school districts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All throughout biology, differences are important: our belly is different from our back, our liver different than our stomach. These differences are generated in an orderly way during the process of development from a single fertilized egg, and are visible manifestations of decisions made at the microscopic level. On the surface of plant leaves, it is easy to see, measure and alter a set of cellular decisions that form the progenitors of stomatal guard cells.  Stomata are pores through which carbon dioxide from the atmosphere enters plants (where it is used during photosynthesis to make sugars) and from which water vapor and oxygen (critical for animal breathing) emerge.  Plants make more or fewer stomata depending on their needs and the environment they find themselves in.  To allow this flexibility, the precursors for the guard cells are part of a stem cell lineage; the hallmark of stem cells is that they can divide to renew themselves and make a second different cell. This division is called an asymmetric cell division and is often accompanied by the differential distribution of substances to one, but not the other, daughter cell.  In addition, a stem cell may divide in a certain direction that puts the daughters in contact with different neighbors, each of which might send signals to influence the behavior of the new cell.

The impact of the work in this proposal is in two major fields. First, it identified the proteins required for plant cells to divide asymmetrically and how the proteins act together to ensure that stomata form in the right place and in the right amounts.  Much of this work focused on the novel protein BASL. BASL is found in the nucleus of the cell, but then, before an asymmetric division, BASL moves to one edge of the cell so that when the cell divides, this edge is always part of the larger cell. Having a protein that is only distributed to one cell is a start, but how does it get there? What does it do there? How do many cells talk to one another so that they organize where BASL goes on a collective level? These are the questions answered in this proposal by using a variety of techniques: microscopy, biochemistry to look at proteins binding to one another, and genetics to see what happens overall if the proteins are altered.  The major discoveries were that BASL relies on partner proteins with the ability to attach to the cell membrane in order to be correctly distributed during cell divisions. 

The second major topic addressed by the work in this proposal was how signals can be specific. There are many mobile signals floating around the body. Many cells have receptors to accept these signals, but what if the signal goes off course? How does the same receiver listen to only the correct signals?  We found that receptors used throughout the body listen only to “stomatal” signals because they partner with a receptor found only in the epidermis.  When this partner is present, the receptors are tuned to perceive only 3 of 11 small mobile signals. When the partner is absent (as in the internal tissues normally, or in the case of mutants), then the receptors are tuned to a different three signals.

As a CAREER grant, this project also had an impact on promoting science literacy for the general public and for training undergraduate students to consider how to present complex specialized information in a way that has resonance for the general public.  Using an undergraduate course on biological communication as a backdrop, we created several products designed to help explain genetics to K-12 students in combination with the San Jose Museum of Technology (The Tech).
